title: How to Make Freezer Jam

steps.headline: Wash the strawberries.
steps.description: Hull them. Crush or grind the strawberries finely.

steps.headline: Measure the crushed strawberries.
steps.description: Add to a large bowl with the lemon juice.

steps.headline: Measure the sugar into a bowl.
steps.description: Be exact or the recipe will not work.

steps.headline: Add the pectin.
steps.description: Stir through. Set aside while the pectin dissolves. This will take half an hour.

steps.headline: Pour the light syrup into the crushed strawberries.
steps.description: Mix together well. The syrup prevents the sugar from crystallizing when it freezes.

steps.headline: Add the sugar.
steps.description: Add it bit by bit and stir well. When it dissolves completely, the jam is ready.

steps.headline: Pour the jam into the freezer containers.
steps.description: Do not fill to the tops; instead, leave 1/2 inch/ 1.2 cm space from the top of the jam to the lid to allow the jam to expand during freezing.

steps.headline: Allow to set.
steps.description: Let the jam sit at room temperature for 24 hours. Add a label and date the jam.

steps.headline: Keep in the cold.
steps.description: It can stored in the freezer for up to 1 year, and in the fridge for up to 3 weeks.

steps.headline: Remove the peel from the peaches.
steps.description: Remove the pit. Chop or crush the peaches.

steps.headline: Mix the crushed peaches with the sugar and lemon juice in a mixing bowl.
Add the Ultra Gel in gradual amounts.
steps.description: Stir constantly to dissolve.

steps.headline: Set aside.
steps.description: Allow to stand for 5 minutes.

steps.headline: Transfer to the containers.
steps.description: Label and date.

steps.headline: Place in the cold.
steps.description: It can stored in the freezer for up to 6 months, and in the fridge for up to 2 weeks.

steps.headline: Put the apricots, lemon juice and sugar into a large mixing bowl.
steps.description: Stir to mix the sugar through completely. Set aside for 10 minutes.

steps.headline: In a small saucepan, add 3/4 cup of water to the pectin.
steps.description: Bring to the boil, stirring constantly, boiling and stirring for 1 minute.

steps.headline: Add the pectin mixture straight from the saucepan into the fruit.
steps.description: Stir for 3 minutes.

steps.headline: Transfer the apricot jam into clean jars.
steps.description: Leave 1/2 inch/ 1/5cm space from the top of the jam to the lid, for expansion.

steps.headline: Add the lids.
steps.description: Let stand in the refrigerator until it sets; this should not be any longer than 24 hours. It can be eaten immediately or stored. Label and date each jar.

steps.headline: Store.
steps.description: Refrigerate for up to 3 weeks, or freeze for up to 1 year. Upon thawing (in the fridge), consumer within 3 weeks.

steps.headline: Place the cleaned and hulled strawberries into a food processor or blender.
steps.description: Blend or process to a rough pulp texture.

steps.headline: In a separate bowl, add the Splenda and fruit pectin.
steps.description: Mix to combine well.

steps.headline: Add the strawberry pulp to the pectin mixture.
steps.description: Stir well for 3 minutes.

steps.headline: Transfer to the freezer containers.
steps.description: Let stand for 3 minutes to allow the jam to thicken.

steps.headline: Store.
steps.description: Either keep in the fridge for up to a month or in the freezer for up to 1 year. Label and date each container.

text: Strawberry freezer jam Wash the strawberries. Hull them. Crush or grind the strawberries finely. Measure the crushed strawberries. Add to a large bowl with the lemon juice. Measure the sugar into a bowl. Be exact or the recipe will not work. Add the pectin. Stir through. Set aside while the pectin dissolves. This will take half an hour. Pour the light syrup into the crushed strawberries. Mix together well. The syrup prevents the sugar from crystallizing when it freezes. Add the sugar. Add it bit by bit and stir well. When it dissolves completely, the jam is ready. Pour the jam into the freezer containers. Do not fill to the tops; instead, leave 1/2 inch/ 1.2 cm space from the top of the jam to the lid to allow the jam to expand during freezing. Allow to set. Let the jam sit at room temperature for 24 hours. Add a label and date the jam. Keep in the cold. It can stored in the freezer for up to 1 year, and in the fridge for up to 3 weeks. Peach freezer jam Remove the peel from the peaches. Remove the pit. Chop or crush the peaches. Mix the crushed peaches with the sugar and lemon juice in a mixing bowl.  Add the Ultra Gel in gradual amounts. Stir constantly to dissolve. Set aside. Allow to stand for 5 minutes. Stir again to make smooth.  Transfer to the containers. Label and date. Place in the cold. It can stored in the freezer for up to 6 months, and in the fridge for up to 2 weeks. Apricot freezer jam Put the apricots, lemon juice and sugar into a large mixing bowl. Stir to mix the sugar through completely. Set aside for 10 minutes. In a small saucepan, add 3/4 cup of water to the pectin. Bring to the boil, stirring constantly, boiling and stirring for 1 minute. Add the pectin mixture straight from the saucepan into the fruit. Stir for 3 minutes. Transfer the apricot jam into clean jars. Leave 1/2 inch/ 1/5cm space from the top of the jam to the lid, for expansion. Add the lids. Let stand in the refrigerator until it sets; this should not be any longer than 24 hours. It can be eaten immediately or stored. Label and date each jar. Store. Refrigerate for up to 3 weeks, or freeze for up to 1 year. Upon thawing (in the fridge), consumer within 3 weeks. Sugar-free freezer jam Place the cleaned and hulled strawberries into a food processor or blender. Blend or process to a rough pulp texture. In a separate bowl, add the Splenda and fruit pectin. Mix to combine well. Add the strawberry pulp to the pectin mixture. Stir well for 3 minutes. Transfer to the freezer containers. Let stand for 3 minutes to allow the jam to thicken. Store. Either keep in the fridge for up to a month or in the freezer for up to 1 year. Label and date each container.
